column56: NHS Swale CCG Community Adult Anti-Coagulation Service
column57:
The aim of this service is for a lead provider to deliver Swale CCG's primary monitoring, dosing and prescribing service for patients aged 18 or over, mobile or housebound, who require warfarin anticoagulation management and are registered with a Swale CCG GP practice, in line with National Guidance. The service will have equitable access and will ensure that patients are treated with dignity and respect, are fully informed about their care and are able to make decisions about their care in partnership with healthcare professionals. The service will aim to provide patients with care close to home, preferably within their own GP surgery. The overarching aims of this monitoring service are:  To provide standardised and clinically effective anticoagulation management to patients receiving warfarin therapy whilst minimising the risks associated with anticoagulation  To offer transfer of care from hospital to primary care clinics for appropriate patients that have received initiated loading doses and have a reading within range as per the NPSA guidance  To produce optimum management of INR control using near patient testing.  Continue to educate patients in understanding their treatment, in terms of their condition requiring warfarin, target range for INR, the effects of over and under anticoagulation, diet, lifestyle and drug interactions  To appropriately manage patients who are over anti-coagulated, and assist GP to refer to specialist services where appropriate  To maintain a register of all patients receiving warfarin and have a treatment plan for each patient that is reviewed on a regular basis  To review the need for continuation of therapy  To identify and manage appropriately patients with specific needs i.e. poor compliance, unstable INR control or frequent non attendees  To optimise care to patients receiving warfarin therapy in terms of accessibility, continuity and waiting times, including home visiting as required by patient need.  To ensure complete and accurate documentation of the clinic process and ensuring a full record of each patient's medication and treatment plan is stored both on the patient's GP record and the dispensing pharmacy of the patient's choice.  To provide each patient with a yellow book to keep a record of all anti-coagulation therapy results and dosages.  Ensure the NPSA safety alert 18 (Actions that can make anticoagulation therapy safer) March 2007 is implemented by the provider Due to the introduction and increased uptake of NOACs the value of the contract may depreciate over the life of the contract. The contract value stated is based on the ultimate contract term of five years consisting of an initial 36 months with the option to extend by one 24 month increment to a total contract length of 60 months.

This future opportunity notice is intended to provide interested suppliers with the opportunity to gain Information and an understanding of a potential Department of Health (DH) requirement, and to provide information to interested suppliers about the associated supplier day which will be run in Central London on the morning of the 25th July. 
The requirement - Under section 12(2) of the Mental Health Act 1983 (“the MHA”) the Secretary of State for Health approves, for the purposes of that section, registered medical practitioners who have "special experience in the diagnosis or treatment of mental disorder”(“s12 doctors”). Additionally, under section 145(1) of the MHA, the Secretary of State is to approve persons to act as “an approved clinician for the purposes of the Act” (“Approved Clinicians”). These functions are collectively referred to as ‘the Approval functions’.
The Approval functions have been vested in the Secretary of State since the enactment of the MHA, but had been delegated by virtue of regulations made under the National Health Service Act 1977 and directions issued under the National Health Service Act 2006, most recently to Strategic Health Authorities (“SHAs”). 
SHAs ceased to exist when the relevant provisions in the Health and Social Care Act 2012 came into force. The Department of Health became responsible for the Approval functions. Following a review and a procurement exercise the Secretary of State contracted with four approving bodies. These contracts are due to terminate on 31st March 2017. The Department of Health (“DH”) plans to seek bids from organisations to provide the services as described in the attached draft procurement documentation (the specification, ITT part B). As this notice (and the published prior Information notice) are at pre-procurement (pre Invitation to Tender) stage, the attached documents are therefore draft and for Information only, may change and may not fully reflect any eventual final versions.
The proposed Contract will cover four regions as described in the documentation; being Lot 1, Panel one - North of England. Lot 2, Panel Two - Midlands and East. Lot 3, Panel Three - London. Lot 4, Panel Four - South of England.

column56: PHE - Corporate ICT - Diabetic Eye Screening data collection and management
column57:
PHE are looking for a supplier with considerable experience in the health care and medical sector to provide data collection and management services 

General Practice to Diabetic Retinopathy Screening (GP2DRS) is a system intended to automate and improve the accuracy of patient cohort identification within the NHS Diabetic Eye screening programme (NDESP).  The system utilises data extraction tools provided and supported by the Health and Social Care Information Centre’s (HSCIC) GP Extraction Service (GPES) to identify patients with diabetes in GP practice IT systems. The identification depends on the accurate clinical coding of diabetic patients within GP systems.  The data is then collated by GPES, processed and sent to the GP2DRS database whereby it is made available to the 70 local screening programmes to update their databases.
The system is currently in pilot at 5 screening programmes.  The quality of the data being received from the system needs to be validated to ensure that the system can be deployed widely across England.
The chosen partner will manage the process of assuring the quality of the data being collected via GPES and ensuring that the data is aligned to the extraction specification and capable of being used by the screening programmes. The supplier must have the following essential experience and expertise:
1.	Experience of the Diabetic Eye Screening Dataset and the screening programme operations in relation to data collection and management.
2.	Expertise in the application and identification of READ codes in GP surgeries that use the EMIS, TPP, INPS and Microtest systems.
3.	Expertise in the use of Miquest query building and application.
4.	Expertise and experience in working with GPES, HSCIC, GP system suppliers, NHS screening programmes, third party suppliers and Public Health England agencies in the assurance of clinical IT systems.

column56: Desistance and Disengagement Programme – Mentoring Services
column57:
In the 2015 Counter Extremism Strategy, the Government committed to deliver a new de-radicalisation programme aimed at changing the behaviour (desistence) and beliefs (disengagement, or ‘deradicalisation’) of those who have already engaged in terrorist-related activity or who are further down the path to radicalisation than those for whom the Channel Programme was designed.
• The new Desistance and Disengagement programme will focus on those convicted of terrorism, or terrorism related offences, who have served their custodial sentences and are due to be released on licence.
• The programme will address the complex range of needs and factors that lead individuals to become involved in terrorism, and will run alongside statutory risk assessment and management processes such
as the Multi Agency Public Protection Arrangements (‘MAPPA’).
• In addition to the existing interventions already available through those statutory partners, we believe an additional suite of psychological, theological and social/occupational provisions and mentoring will
provide the best possible means for these individuals to disengage from extremism and reintegrate safely back into society.
 • We recognise the skills and expertise the third sector holds in facilitating and encouraging social integration into society. We are therefore tendering for a Non-Governmental Organisation to deliver the
mentoring aspect of the programme.
• This mentoring services contract is a 15 month pilot study. It will commence on the 1st October 2016 and will expire on the 31st December 2017. Should the pilot prove successful, the Authority may wish to extend contract services to 31st March 2020. Option periods are defined in the tender documentation.

Additional information: Please note, deadline for submission of bids 15/08/2016 18:00 BST.

column56: Provision of Utility Monitoring Software
column57:
The University of Birmingham is well on the way to meeting its commitment to reducing its carbon footprint by 20% by 2020. To underpin this objective it operates an energy monitoring, targeting and reporting system which receives data from around 2,000 AMR meters and 1,000 non AMR hourly meters (400 of which are invoiced by utility suppliers) for electricity, heat, steam, gas and water.  This data is provided by a number of sources including utility suppliers, text messages, SFTP transfer via the in-house data collection system using Modbus and M-bus.  The data collected is used to produce a variety of reports to support the management of energy costs and consumption, provide feedback to users of the building, compliance reporting (E.g. EU ETS and Display Energy Certificates), charging third parties and by the in-house team who need an overview of utility use on-site and variances together with the ability to interrogate the lowest level of metering.

The University requires a software solution that will provide a cost effective means of recording utility consumption, verifying and producing invoices, analysing and reporting its consumption of energy and water and the resulting carbon footprint.  We also desire to use this information together with other sources (e.g. the Schneider Building Management System) to provide feedback to consumers of energy/water.

NHS England are seeking Expressions of Interest (EOI) from providers who have the capability and capacity to undertake a contract for the provision of primary medical services to patients in the Chatham area of Kent and wish to take part in a potential procurement exercise.

The procurement is likely to commence in August 2016, and the new contract is due to begin in April 2017.

The procurement will be for the College Health practice in Chatham.

The contract term is envisaged to be for an initial 3 year period, with the option to renew for a further 2 years; this is subject to approval and the precise term will be advised at a later date.  The contract will have an annual value in the region of £620,000.  More detail will be available as the procurement process proceeds.

The vision at Medway Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG) is to help people keep healthy and active and live longer healthier lives; not waiting until people become unwell for the health service to see them.

We recognise our role in reducing health inequalities in terms of both outcomes and access to services, and have placed prevention and health improvement at the heart of our strategic plan.

Medway CCG comprises 53 GP member practices from across the Medway towns, responsible for planning and buying local NHS services, serving a practice population of 309,033.

Our 2015/16 annual report identifies the following key points:

•	According to the Office for National Statistics’ (ONS) mid-2013 population estimate, Medway's resident population is 271,105, an increase of 21,405 (8.6%) since 2001.. However net out-migration since 2001 has reduced overall population growth over this period.

•	Approximately 2,000 Medway residents die each year (2,072 deaths in 2013), with significantly higher mortality rates found in males than females.

•	The majority of the population (85.9%) in Medway are classified as White British, with the next largest ethnic group being Asian or Asian British (5.0% - not including Chinese). The three wards with the most ethnically diverse school populations are Chatham Central, Gillingham south and River wards.

•	The population of Medway is slightly younger than the national average with a median of 37.7 years of age compared to the England median of 39.9 years.


•	2011 to 2037 projections suggest that the proportion of the population aged 65 years or over will increase from 14.0% (37,200) to 21.4% (70,000). The equivalent change in those aged 85 years and over is from 1.7% (4,400) to 3.7% (12,000).
•	The number of people over 65 years with a limiting long-term illness is expected to increase by 48.3% from 2014 to 2030, which would have a significant impact on the demand for health services for the management of long-term conditions such as dementia, heart disease and diabetes as the incidence of these conditions increases with age.

Additional information: The outcomes that NHS England wishes to secure from the procurement include:
* Sustainable primary care, working at scale, based on Local Care Teams, aimed at integrating community based services around local populations
* Good access to services, both in Core Hours and beyond
* High quality management of long term conditions and health promotion

A Market event will take place on July 20th between 12.30 and 2.00 in the Medway area, to provide potential bidders with the opportunity to ask questions and hear more detail of the procurement process. column56: Consultancy Support in the Preparation of a Housing Revenue Account Asset Management Strategy
column57:
Stoke-on-Trent City Council is seeking to appoint a consultant to support the development and consultation of its Housing Revenue Account Housing Asset Management Strategy. It is looking to commission the production of a Housing Asset Management Strategy to inform the maintenance, development and management of its housing stock into the future.   This is an important strategy, and therefore will require consultants to have demonstrable experience of developing strategies in a collaborative way with key officers and stakeholders, to ensure the brief is fulfilled.  

Stoke-on-Trent City Council is a stock holding authority with circa 18,600 properties within its Housing Revenue Account property portfolio, with associated assets including garage sites, shops and cleared land.  Occupied by a diverse range of tenants.  

The Council’s housing stock is the Council’s highest value asset and within this the repairs and maintenance of the stock is the Council’s largest liability, therefore successful planning for its sustainable future is therefore vital.

Whilst the council will continue to place primary focus on management, maintenance and refurbishment of existing stock through a major works programme which is driven by the council’s approach to achieving stock decency, the intention is to look at the wider scope of the asset base through the development of the Housing Revenue Account Asset Management Strategy.  This may include the use of vacant sites, the potential redevelopment of existing sites and the potential use of Housing Revenue Account funds for acquisition and/or development of new property.

Additional information: For a copy of the quotation documents please contact Matthew LeDoux-Deakin  email: Matthew.LeDoux-Deakin@stoke.gov.uk

column56: Technical Standards Safety Review
column57:
During the parliamentary design of the Phase One railway a number of Deliverable Approach Statements (DAS) were raised to provide the technical requirements and associated guidance for the design of the railway within the parliamentary design scope. As part of the specification design phase these DAS were updated to Technical Standards to include changes to the design and specific route wide requirements.

As part of the parliamentary design a functional definition of the new High Speed Railway (HSR) was assessed through the System Safety principles and the DAS were used as evidence to show that design decisions taken did not preclude the possibility of hazard acceptance within the more detailed design stages. However, the DAS and Technical Standards have not been fully reviewed to identify where safety requirements have been raised and where they form the basis for hazard acceptance in accordance with the HS2 Railway System Safety Strategy.

Therefore the scope of the services required by this contract is to review the approximately 51 Technical Standards to: 
•	Identify safety requirements listed in the Technical Standards;
•	Identify if the clauses in the Technical Standards are likely to close the hazards under the Common Safety Method on Risk Assessment (CSM-RA); 
•	Suggest the mechanism through which the hazard is closed from those under CSM-RA; and
•	Identify clauses where additional risk assessment is necessary in order to manage the hazard.

For full scope please see Appendix D Schedule of Requirements

column56: Sutton Scarsdale Hall: Wall and plaster consolidation Works - AWARD
column57:
This contract is to undertake works at Sutton Scarsdale Hall which is an unroofed three storey building with a grade 1 listing and Scheduled Monument status. This is the first stage of tender process and will be used to compile a tender list that will consist of between 4 – 6 contractors.  
The works to the site are to take place over 2 phases. The first phase is to include for the consolidation of high level masonry to the roof level of the building and to areas of masonry where required and as specified in the following locations; the servants hall, the smoking room and two adjourning room. 
As well as the conservation of the only remaining original plaster on the site, this will need a specialist contractor to complete the works in line with a report and recommendations produced by Skillington workshop Ltd. Plaster works include for the consolidation of; decorative plaster in the new hall/billiard room, roman cement across the courtyard and plain plaster to the servants hall, the smoking room and two adjourning room.
The second phase is likely to include similar masonry and plain plaster consolidation in the remaining rooms, this may be a negotiated as part of this tender using the standard schedule of rates or sent out as a new competitive tender. 
This project will be an Exemplar project which will help to set the standards for future conservation works and will be reviewed by Historic England inspectors.
